audio_caption: The clip begins with upbeat, folk-style acoustic guitar music. This fades as a male speaker begins, stating he's out doing some scouting and right now is next to what was a Civil War artillery post. He adds that he's only been there about 15 minutes and got a "ten thirty-two signal." He then describes popping out what he believes is a pretty old spoon. He mentions that he looked on the back, but doesn't see any markings, and he hopes this is an indication that there are still some old targets in the ground there. A faint, indiscernible ambient sound can be heard. The clip ends with a man asking a question, "What kind of bottle is that?"

The audio clip begins with the sound of rustling, possibly leaves or paper, followed by a male voice expressing surprise at an object, stating he hasn't seen one like it before, and reading "New Grape Bottle". He notes its age and decides to take it. More rustling precedes his mention of another broken bottle with a cork top. The man discovers "some old bottles up in here," finds one cool, and states "that is cool." A transition to apparent open air introduces the man describing his discovery of a bottle dump. He notes finding a "Cedartown Georgia Coca-Cola bottle," adding he's "gonna hang on to that one". He sees more and offers to show any other "cool ones" he finds. The clip ends with the man saying he invited "the whole crew out," suggesting a search or expedition is beginning.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker mentioning names, including "James", "Silvano", "David", and "Jeff", while discussing their locations, stating some are on the other side of a hill and others "haven't made it out here yet." A distinct bleating sound is then heard.

The clip begins with male speech, stating a number and a measurement, followed by an announcement. The sound of static and squeaking precedes the sound of digging and shuffling, presumably in dirt or sand. The male voice resumes, indicating he believes something is "out of the hole", followed by a distinctive beeping sound. The speaker then identifies a discovery and indicates its composition. The clip concludes with the speaker expressing satisfaction.

The audio begins with the sound of speech. A single male speaker mentions finding an old axe head, emphasizing its weight, and suggests it might be from the Civil War era. The speaker sounds curious and slightly awed. The audio appears to be recorded outdoors, suggested by ambient environmental sounds in the background.

The audio clip opens with speech describing the range of an "1134", followed by shuffling sounds. The speaker is male, with a matter-of-fact tone. A metal detector beeping sound is prominent and consistent, suggesting a search activity. As the metal detector noises continue, the speaker says "not very deep".  The metal detector sounds persist, then the speaker asks "What is that?" with curiosity, as the tone shifts to one of focus. The beeping persists as the speaker explains what they've found, noting that "something written on there." The speaker points out that the writing is backwards, suggesting a stamp, and the audio concludes with the speaker saying they will cut in "for just a minute" because "this actually turned out to be a really neat find."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing a historical artifact he found, mentioning that it seemed like a "stamp or printing plate." He then details how he cleaned it up and reversed the image, revealing a woman who turns out to be "Pauline Frederick," an American actress known for silent films, specifically "Sleeping Fires." He believes the plate was used to make flyers or advertisements for the movie. The speaker sounds excited about his discovery, saying, "That's the kind of stuff I really like to find. That's pretty neat," before returning to the video. The audio transitions to a higher-pitched continuous beeping tone, accompanied by a digger.

The audio clip begins with the sound of digging, followed by speech in a neutral tone, where the speaker notes that "this is more of a surface" and then later identifies "an old pocket knife". Intermittently, a beeping sound can be heard, seemingly related to the digging activity.

The audio clip begins with sounds of wind.  A single male speaker notes having received a "swirly sounding 11-11 signal" and shares that it "turned out to be a V nickel." He then comments that the coin has "seen better days" and "looks like it's been shot," before estimating that the date is 189. The wind sound persists in the background.

The audio clip begins with speech from a male speaker, stating a number. Immediately afterward, an alarm or detector sound occurs, followed by a snippet of speech from a male voice, mentioning specific numbers and indicating a distance, and an Indian head penny range. Background noises present include animal sounds, possibly crow-like calls. The sound of rustling leaves is also audible. This is followed by more animal sounds, including those that sound like a domestic animal.  The male voice speaks again, determining that something is a musket ball.

The clip begins with a man describing the recovery of a makeup compact from the ground, indicating that he got a signal of "11:47," then the shovel sound. He states that it "popped out," and he is excited to open it and see what's inside. The recording then shifts to an acoustic guitar, with a folksy mood.
